newsitem.title: USA: Natgas producers protest U.S. plan for royalties.
newsitem.headline: Natgas producers protest U.S. plan for royalties.

text.p: Major U.S. natural gas producers said Thursday they had protested a plan by the Minerals Management Service to change the way it calculates royalties owed for gas produced on federal and Indian lands.
MMS had proposed to base the royalties on prices of natural gas after it has been processed, rather than at the wellhead.

In an October 30 letter to the agency, members of the Natural Gas Supply Association (NGSA) said they were "deeply troubled" by the plan that would include marketing costs in gas price valuations, and urged MMS to withdraw the proposal.
"Marketing costs are not production costs," NGSA said in the letter released Thursday.
The group added that tracking natural gas sales from the wellhead to the burnertip would entail heavy administrative costs for the industry.
The agency expects to come out with a new proposal or a final rule no earlier than mid-1997, based on comments from the industry and other parties, an MMS spokesman said.
"There's a possibility they might have to come out with another proposed rule," because of strong opposition voiced in comments, which were due in August, the spokesman said.
The agency's proposal made in July came on top of another rule change in progress for calculating royalties based on published index prices, a plan which it had negotiated with the industry.
MMS, which collects about $4 billion a year in oil, gas and mineral royalties, has been under pressure from Congress and a watchdog group to pursue royalties more aggressively.
